ThenActions.Text:
<!--
This text file is used by a Keyboard Maestro macro named: 
%ExecutingMacro%

Each line in this file contains an 𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘅, the 𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗵 to a 
Favorite Folder, and an 𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗸𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗲. If the nickname is specified, 
the macro will display it rather than the path when generating 
'Prompt With List' items. A nickname can contain any text including 
colons. For very long paths, it is sometimes helpful to include a 
subset of the path string. For example,

  > path: ~/Documents/My Business/New Clients/S/Smith Widget Co
  > possible nickname: ~/Docs/…/Smith Widget Co

The optional prefix of one or more letters 𝗺𝗸𝘇𝗰𝗮𝗻 (representing 
𝗠𝗼𝘃𝗲, 𝗞𝗲𝗲𝗽, 𝗭𝗶𝗽, 𝗖𝗼𝗽𝘆, 𝗔𝗹𝗶𝗮𝘀, 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗲) followed by two colons (::) is 
used to limit when the Favorite Folder is used. For example, 
𝗻::~:𝗛𝗼𝗺𝗲 would be a Favorite Folder for the user Home folder, but 
only for the 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗲 option.

Notes:
  1. A tilde (~) can be used in specified paths to represent a 
     user's Home folder. Alternatively the full path can be used.

  2. The contents of this file are typically managed by the macro. 
     Whenever a change is made, the previous version is automatically 
     discarded into the trash.

  3. Using a text editor, lines can be rearranged. The order in this 
     file will be used by 'Prompt With List' actions in the macro.

%ExecutingMacro% 𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 (a.k.a. 𝗩𝗲𝗿𝗯𝘀):
• 𝗠𝗼𝘃𝗲: move item(s)
• 𝗞𝗲𝗲𝗽: move item(s); create an alias(es) in the item(s) original location
• 𝗘𝗻𝗰𝗹𝗼𝘀𝗲: create a folder and move the item(s) into it
• 𝗭𝗶𝗽: zip item(s)
• 𝗖𝗼𝗽𝘆: copy item(s)
• 𝗔𝗹𝗶𝗮𝘀: create alias(es)
• 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗰𝗲: replace an alias(es) with the original item(s)
• 𝗧𝗮𝗴: use various tagging functions
• 𝗪𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗲 New File/Folder: create a file or folder
• 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗲: open a folder
• 𝗦𝗮𝘃𝗲: save a folder to this file

ThenActions.Title: %ExecutingMacro%
ThenActions.Prompt:
MACRO CANCELLED—Could not create: %Variable%local_FFFPath_Label%

MORE INFORMATION:
%Variable%local_ActionResult%…

Welcome to %ExecutingMacro%!

This macro provides a means to complete common Finder tasks—with minimal use of the mouse. 

When the macro is triggered, the 𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 (a.k.a. 𝗩𝗲𝗿𝗯𝘀: e.g., 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗲, 𝗠𝗼𝘃𝗲, 𝗖𝗼𝗽𝘆, 𝗧𝗮𝗴) presented will be context sensitive—i.e., within the Finder: no items selected, one item selected, more than one item selected.

Default 𝗙𝗮𝘃𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 settings have been written to:

%Variable%local_FFFPath_Label%

In general, this text file (a.k.a. 𝗙𝗙𝗙) is managed automatically by the macro; however, it can be opened and modified with any text editor.

One advantage of opening this text file is that it includes several comments including a short explanation of each macro 𝗩𝗲𝗿𝗯. Note that some of these 𝗩𝗲𝗿𝗯𝘀 are creatively named so that options can be most efficiently selected.

👉🏿 If the 𝗙𝗙𝗙 is moved, 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝗹_𝗙𝗮𝘃𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗙𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗵 must be updated.
%Variable%local_InvisibleChar%
